content.text: Do you have any suggestions on how to resolve this? After looking at it, it looks like the company code signup flow is part of the product design and is needed in order to have users register with the correct company. Even if we switch the api response to a redirect, one would still be able to differentiate between a valid and invalid code based on the kind of redirect or error. Further, what is the concern here with people finding out valid company codes? Looks like the only data that would be seen is the company name, and what products they offer. Please advise, thank you
have you had a chance to review this ticket?
This finding is Company code enumeration attack. According to comment below comment from Emanuel, company code and product data is not considered sensitive info. What can we do in this case?
If Company Code is NOT publicly available information, then we must find a way to protect it.  Allowing a threat actor to harvest valid company codes could be used to facilitate another attack.

I understand, but this is designed into how the product itself and how it is sold to our customers. Changing this is a significant effort, especially for a product that is being retired in a year, and would need more involvement from the product team. The company codes only purpose is to facilitate user signup, and I guess Iâ€™m asking for more specifics on what the perceived risks are to someone harvesting all the company codes? In my eyes, this might as well be public information, and Iâ€™m struggling to see the harm here.
Weâ€™ll need a firm and committed date to decommission the site before we can submit for an exception.  Do we have that date yet?
also, we only have 30 clients and less than 60 subscribers
- The fixes are required by Feb 7, 2025.  If you wish to obtain an exception to not address these issues, a write up needs to be approved by Anand.  Thanks
If possible, applications should avoid incorporating user-controllable data into redirection targets. In many cases, this behavior can be avoided in a number of ways:
Remove the redirection function from the application, and replace links to it with direct links to the relevant target URLs.
Maintain a server-side list of all URLs that are permitted for redirection. Instead of passing the target URL as a parameter to the redirector, pass an index into this list.

If it is considered unavoidable for the redirection function to receive user-controllable input and incorporate this into the redirection target, one of the following measures should be used to minimize the risk of redirection attacks:
The application should use relative URLs in all of its redirects, and the redirection function should strictly validate that the URL received is a relative URL.

The application should use URLs relative to the web root for all of its redirects, and the redirection function should validate that the URL received starts with a slash character. It should then prepend
to the URL before issuing the redirect.
The application should use absolute URLs for all of its redirects, and the redirection function should verify that the user-supplied URL begins with
merge the two step signup into one step
add company code to personal info form
handle company code validation in same endpoint
return generic error regardless of what went wrong
Enumeration vulnerabilities occur when a web application reveals whether or not a particular username, userID or file ID exists on a system.
This may be by design, or as a consequence of misconfiguration. This information can be used to either glean information directly, or to launch further attacks.

During testing it was noted that the company code on the signup page can be brute forced in an attempt to enumerate other valid company codes. It was possible to automate the submission of thousands of codes without facing any mechanism to prevent or slow down the attack.
In addition to the company code provided to us for testing, we were also able to identify an additional legitimate value, â€˜testâ€™, which is tied to the company Hennessey Engineers Inc.
Error message enabling easy differentiation between registered and non-registered company codes:
Automated brute forcing of thousands of company codes:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:128.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/128.0
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:128.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/128.0
